Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Phase II: Center for Electromagnetic Compatibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
The IUCRC for Electromagnetic Compatibility (CEMC) proposes renewal as a two-site I/UCRC, comprising personnel and facilities at the Missouri University of Science and Technology and the University of Houston. CEMC's industry sector requires understanding of noise physics, development of innovative measurement and modeling techniques, and formulation of design methodologies. This includes immunity and electromagnetic interference (EMI), which ensures an electronic system: (1) can function in the presence of external electromagnetic noise; and, (2) its EMI does not impact the functionality of other devices. Signal and power integrity design ensures proper circuit operation at high speeds. Phase II efforts will target development of methods for higher frequencies and smaller geometry scales.

Design for electromagnetic compatibility is critical in electronics. Good electromagnetic compatibility design is essential to successful product development, customer satisfaction and industry competitiveness. Research outcomes from CEMC in Phase I include 31 students graduated from the center and numerous hires of students by industry members. There were over 50 publications and one spin-off company during Phase I with research results incorporated into university courses, and on-site and on-line company short courses. Research outcomes in Phase II will be disseminated through the center website, publications, technical conferences, short courses, IEEE EMC Society committee activities, spin-off companies, and industry application notes. Demonstrations suitable for motivating interest in K-12 students in technical careers are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CEMC has contributed to the field of EMC in a significant way.  The member companies have been benefited with better fundamental understanding, effective solutions to mitigate and prevent EMC problems, improved engineering design flow and guidelines, as well as well-trained work force.  The field of EMC as a whole has also been impacted by the disseminated research outcomes and outreach.  EMC is no more black magic but science.  We strongly believe that the CEMC as well as the Missouri S&T site, with significant development in Phases I and II, has already established the necessary expertise, infrastructure, resources and a collaborative industry/university team, and is well positioned to address the growing challenges, and help industry continue to advance technology.  

 

Our research outcome can be summarized in the following three tiers.

 

At the first tier level, we worked on fundamental research tasks such as statistical electromagnetic modeling, uncertainty analysis, equivalent medium theorem for safety assessment, and fundamental electromagnetic interference with neuron-engineering. In the past 15 years, our research group has extended collaboration with several research centers at FDA and has had the research collaboration agreement (RCA) with them for over a decade (initially the RCA is under different name). The results of these collaborations have led to 1) over 20 joint scientific publications, 2) new FDA guidance documents, 3) important technical achievements that have been included in both ISO standards for medical safety and ASTM standard for device safety evaluation.

 

At the second tier level, we developed enabling technologies that can be commercialized and make direct impact on medical device EMC standard. In the past ten years, the center at University of Houston has developed various enabling tools to understand the interactions between implantable devices with external electromagnetic interferences and its impact on human bodies. Some of these novel fundamental research results have not seen its commercial and economic impacts. Our goal is to ensure that these advances in EMC research can lead to enabling technologies that can make impact towards the well being for of human society. This will include better device testing methodologies for both active medical implantable devices and passive medical implantable devices, as well as the improvement of medical device electrode designs.

 

At the third tier level, we have integrated a closed-loop neuro-stimulator system via a spin off company from our NSF center. This will be the second spin-off company from our center. The first spin-off company focused on providing critical labeling information for medical device manufactures. So far, company has provided such information for over 200 medical device manufactures all over the world. The second spin-off company would develop better neuro-stimulator based on our coupled electromagnetic and neuro-simulation capability that will be described in the later section.
